awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Spectrally-Efficient Near-Zero-Power IoT Connectivity with Existing Wi-Fi Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to truly enable the vision of ubiquitous devices connected to the Internet (Internet-of Things or IoT), connections should be possible with a minimal overhead for deployment, device and operational costs. To limit the deployment overhead, wireless connectivity should occur via existing infrastructure. Unfortunately, the most popular wireless network in enterprises and healthcare facilities is Wi-Fi, and the power consumption of Wi-Fi chipsets is too large (100s of milliwatts) to be easily powered by small coin cell batteries without large operational costs to frequently replace or re-charge batteries. As a result, current deployments of IoT devices (like Google's Nest systems) are limited to locations where they can be plugged into a power source. This issue is currently holding back innovation in new IoT device concepts. Since reducing the power consumption of Wi-Fi transceivers using conventional techniques is not possible, a new communication approach is needed. The primary objective of this proposal is to enable new classes of battery-powered IoT devices that can directly communicate with Wi-Fi access points by just reflecting or backscattering existing Wi-Fi signals. Since backscattering requires only a passive antenna with a reflection circuit with computationally relaxed baseband specifications, low-power operation at the IoT device-level can be achieved. Successful research will enable more rapid adoption of IoT devices into existing infrastructure and will enable new classes of low-power environmental, industrial, smart home, and health monitoring applications. Beyond enabling exciting new applications, the project also proposes a synergistic educational and outreach plan that leverages technical work performed in the grant to build exciting new demos to be used in undergraduate and K-12 classroom settings. For example, a fruit-based energy harvesting system powering the developed low power tags which communicate directly with Wi-Fi devices will introduce students to the wonders of engineering in a pragmatic yet compelling way, with the hope of increasing diversity in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM)-related education environments. 

The proposed work specifically aims to enable the first practical low-power, low-cost integrated circuit solution which can enable a network of backscatter tags to connect with existing and Wi-Fi protocols. It would be the first to include a low-power universal-WiFi wake-up receiver for efficient synchronization and medium access control for the backscatter tags, and then backscatter Wi-Fi compliant signals piggybacked with IoT data. Importantly, the proposed backscatter platform will operate seamlessly with all existing Wi-Fi infrastructure so as to not interfere with existing spectrally-efficient productive communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on creating low-power, accessible IoT connectivity that's compatible with existing WiFi infrastructure. Rather than generating active WiFi signals, our approach revolved around modulating and reflecting existing signals, encoding information in a manner that the reflected signal could be decoded using the current infrastructure. This reflection-based method resulted in ultra-low power IoT connectivity.


Significant strides were made towards improving power efficiency, enhancing the spectral efficiency of backscatter WiFi communication, optimizing network spectral efficiency, and augmenting the long-range readability of backscatter IoT connectivity.


A significant innovation was the creation of a WiFi-compatible hierarchical wake-up receiver that enables near-zero-power operation with precise wake-up synchronization for backscatter communications. The receiver proved its efficacy in wireless tests, responding to signals 20m away and receiving packets up to 10m from the tag.


We also developed a universal tag that optimizes the reflected signal due to integration, thus augmenting the spectral efficiency of backscatter WiFi communication. The tag piggybacks onto existing communication without wasteful packets, preserving network spectral efficiency. We introduced techniques for efficiently managing a network of tags per access point.


We explored tag architectures with multiple antennas to increase the range and ease of deployment for backscatter tags. This enhanced backscattered signal strength and enabled long-range tag readability, making it ideal for extensive networks such as warehouses.

Unlike our previous works requiring at least two external devices, we designed a backscatter tag that can be activated by a single smartphone. This tag, charged by LTE signals, can perform BLE-to-WiFi backscatter, negating the need for batteries. The tag can be powered by an LTE source within a second over 50cm and can self-start to perform backscattering.

The project provided immense learning and professional development opportunities for our team, including three Ph.D. students, a post-doctoral candidate, and one undergraduate student. Regular meetings, presentations, skills training, and preparation for publication were integral parts of our professional growth.

The outcomes of the project have been shared with the scientific community via publications in reputed conferences and journals like IEEE ISSCC, IEEE JSSC, and Usenix (NSDI). They are available publicly on the project's webpage. We also initiated a STEM program for undergraduate students, using demo projects related to our research to spark interest. All our products are available at https://wcsng.ucsd.edu/ubiquitousIoT/


Our research is poised to significantly impact fields that require ultra-low power radios, such as agriculture and asset tracking, and has the potential to revolutionize applications in smart home and environmental monitoring, and wearable devices. In essence, we're contributing a novel, cost-effective, and efficient method for IoT connectivity, bridging the gap between daily-use devices and the expansive Internet of Things realm.
